settings.text: An antiarrhythmic drug called rythmol is used to treat unnatural heartbeats. It functions by suppressing specific electrical signals in the heart that could otherwise result in an erratic heartbeat.Both tablets and extended-release capsules of rythmol are readily available. Three times a day, with or without food, is the usual dosage. Headache, lightheadedness, and nausea are typical adverse reactions.  This article can be used by Welzo users as reference material to learn more about Rythmol.

A number of abnormal heart rhythms are treated with rythmol. These consist of:

- Atrial fibrillation: This type of irregular heartbeat is the most prevalent. About 2.7 million Americans are impacted. Rythmol can assist in maintaining a regular heartbeat and may lessen the danger of blood clots, strokes, and other complications.

- Ventricular tachycardia: The lower chambers of the heart's ventricles are the source of this abnormally high heart rate. Rythmol can lower blood pressure and improve circulation.

Supraventricular tachycardia is a heart rate that begins above the ventricles and is abnormally rapid. Blood flow can be enhanced and the heart rate can be restored with rythmol.

Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is one of the other conditions for which rythmol may be used off-label.

The most typical adverse reactions to rythmol include:

- Migraine

- Vertigo

- Diarrhea

â€¢ diarrhoea

Skin rash

- Tiredness

Angioedema is a rare but potentially dangerous side effect. This illness causes swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat. Stop taking Rythmol immediately and seek medical help if you experience this.

Other uncommon but severe adverse effects include:

- Liver issues

- Heart disease

- A drop in blood cells, which can result in infections, fatigue, and easily bruising or bleeding.

Call your doctor as soon as you notice any of these side effects. If you experience any new or deteriorating symptoms while taking Rythmol, you should also call your doctor.

Both tablets and extended-release capsules of rythmol are readily available. Three times a day at 150 mg is the suggested starting dose. If necessary, your doctor might raise your dose. The maximum dose advised is 300 mg taken three times per day.

You can take rythmol with or without food. It's crucial to take Rythmol precisely as directed by your physician. Avoid skipping doses or stopping the medication abruptly because doing so could cause severe heart rhythm issues.
Rythmol functions by obstructing specific electrical heart signals.This aids in bringing the heart rate back to normal and increases blood flow.

If you take any other medications, herbs, or vitamins, rythmol may interact with them. Your doctor needs to carefully monitor all of your medications to prevent interactions. Tell your doctor about all of your medications, even those that don't appear to be related to your condition.

Drugs that may interact with Rythmol include some of the following:

- Cordarone (amiodarone)

Lanoxin (Digoxin)

- Tambocor (flecainide)

- Lithium (Lithobid, Eskalith)

Quinaglute, Cardioquin, Quinidine

The list of possible drug interactions is not exhaustive. Inquire about additional possible interactions with your doctor or pharmacist.
The gastrointestinal tract is a good source of rythmol absorption, and it has a bioavailability of about 50%.Its elimination half-life is 20 to 40 hours after liver metabolism.
